Chad Fowler in 2012 And in 2014 sorry Martin Fowler And in 2014 a blog post from Martin Fowler Sorry yeah 2013 Still talking about immutable systems How we should be able to rely on a state of the system that is not going to But we are 12 years behind this 12 years after this We're still talking about these problems right Chef and Puppet are great tools were great tools The problem was that they were looking at one aspect of the system So that configuration was the state of the system But an operating system or a server it's much more than that right There are libraries there are patches and packages that need to be And there is mutability that takes care of this Indeed So yeah I don't know how many have seen that movie Terminator 2 It's a bit famous And they had this T 1000 robot that could morph into different shapes right And I think it shows us a very powerful mean tool right And I feel with mutability we get this idea of power that we get with our systems so easy to go and install a It's so easy to go and change a And it makes us feel good I am in control of my system the reality is that that ability to do those changes is actually what brings many problems What kind of problems you might ask Problems like drifting of configuration Sure you might have a configuration management system that is running and putting something in the right state But that system can fail at any point right Leaving you with a system that didn't finish to the desired state So in this way you can find many of those problems Back in 2015 I was working on a tool called Machinery You probably didn't hear of it It was not particularly famous I was very proud how we were doing it Engineering wise I think it was very well done What this tool used to do is that we would go and introspect Linux systems We would go and check the exact way in which it was which packages it had which configurations it had and how different they were from what the upstream maintainers were designed to do And also you could do diffing for example between okay I inspect this system in the morning and I inspect it in the afternoon and I could see the differences between these two systems Very in my opinion elegant It was nice But the problem was that we should have already known how the system should have looked and the system shouldn't have changed There was no reason for the change to And so the problems that come from these kind of really smart tools that we sometimes try to come up with is that yeah something happened with our server Did someone introspect it at the right moment to know what happened No last introspection that was done was I don't know 15 minutes before the issue actually was introduced Too bad right This doesn't bring the solution that we want And this is exactly what we just said right The tools that we had in 2010 in 2009 even are looking at an aspect of the system making sure that that is according to what we want but we're not looking at the entire system We don't have anything that tells us the system has not changed We don't need to change the systems And the question is do you actually need to change the I want to raise a hand Who thinks that the system should mutate throughout the life of the system You think that it should Okay good I have let's see let's go back a moment on that one So what I said before Milan Kundera's tension was between lightness and weight The lightness intended as freedom freedom of thought and impermanent detachment from state and the weight being a responsibility persistence consequence reliability So if we go back from an engineer perspective this is a far fetched right Kundera is a philosopher and let's look at an which philosopher is closest to a physicist but it's okay So we want to deploy fast We want to provision often We want to make sure that we change the system often as Stefan just said Agreed But we also want it to be secure We want it to be reliable We want it to be dependable We want to know what is the state of the system when we are looking at the system and when we are not looking at the So these two things do not match We want to change the system but we want to also know the state of the system That way So at the edge let's bring it to the edge this situation So we have problems at the What we call the weight of the We have systems that are disconnected or partially connected We have systems that are exposed to security concerns right We want to make sure that the system is not compromisable if a bad actor is approaching the system What to replace something to what is supposed to be running And we have an opinion of how that can be achieved with the operating system at Let's see how we take it further By the way if you are into hardware at least I am Can I get a gauge who is into hardware like me I got you guys Nice When we are doing microcode upgrades because the other people call this firmware upgrades but we call it microcode upgrades When we are doing microcode upgrades we are never patching it or we are never actually upgrading it We are always doing something that Mauro will show us on operating systems We are actually replacing the microcode We are always doing something called an A B upgrade So Mauro Thanks William So yeah today I want to talk a little bit about immutable OSes in general but more specifically from the perspective of And part of it is this evolution that we have had through the DevOps lens We were talking about going from pets to cattle right But at the end of the day cattle is still you know like William likes to say sometimes those cows could also be pets right And let's face it some teams sometimes treat some of their cattle like because And why do you think this is the Why do they do it Simply because they can If you couldn't then no reason to think like that And that's why I like to promote the idea of instead of thinking of it as cattle let's think of it as appliances And what would an appliance look like Here I have four characteristics We should not have any snowflakes anymore When I talk about snowflakes mean you deploy a fleet of and one or many of them happen not to be exactly with the description that you intended it to have right It's adrift from the original configuration that you wanted to have in that machine It must have A B or atomic upgrades which is what William was just explaining So in a way I am upgrading the system but in reality I am replacing 100  the previous system with a new system It must be able to do factory resets and recovery so Sorry anybody ever heard of atomic upgrades A B upgrades Yes Okay cool You must be able to do factory resets so let's say I want to repurpose a certain machine I should not be able to do anything more complex than simply tell it to factory reset like we do with our phones for example Maybe our phones is one of the best examples for these two last points A B upgrades most of our phones have been doing a full switch into a new system for a while now but factory reset is the same You just go and I received it originally when I bought it and that's exactly what you get And it should be a declarative configuration which is something that maybe we are already quite used to at this point So which options do I have This is not a final list There is more out there of but these are all operating systems that are running at the CNCF at the moment It all started with CoreOS which is now a Red Hat solution but all of the big players have one option there For example AWS has Bottlerocket there Microsoft has Flatcar SUSE has MicroOS there are other smaller players Today I want to talk to you about the best of all of them Kairos which of course I'm What is Kairos Kairos we like to sell it as an immutable operating system but it's a bit more than that It actually takes an operating system that you already have and mutates it into Sorry I picked the worst word I could have picked right And it transforms it into an immutable system Why is this a good thing It is a good thing because you might be working with a certain customer that requires that you use a certain golden image because that has been vetted by their security team or something like that Well you can bring that image and convert it into a Kairos system If you have already licenses for Red Hat or SUSE you can start from those systems Or if the know how of your team is Ubuntu no problem You start from Ubuntu You need a smaller footprint Arch I You can convert them into Kairos systems So that's I would say on top of the four things that I mentioned before that one of these appliance systems should have one thing that is very unique about us is that we run on multiple Linux distributions Another thing that we try to do also as open is that we allow you to different Kubernetes distributions Right now we support out of the box K0S and K3S and other different distributions And I mean we're happy to get contributions for more than those that we have at the It also has this ability of peer to peer clustering What does that Let's say that you want to start a but you don't want to go into the details of which one should be the control plane and which one should be the workers Well the system will go through a peer to peer network and start deciding who gets to be what in this world Why is this useful Because then you just start spinning up new machines and your cluster can either grow or go down in the amount of workloads that you might need to have right It's 100  container based Many of these operating systems are It supports trusted boot What does that Well secure boot is not enough so that someone might actually change the system that is running on top What you want with these machines is that I provision it for one thing and that one thing only is going to be running in my machine which is the example that William was giving before With trusted boot you can do this Why Because we measure everything We measure not only the disk image that you're putting into that system We measure the kernel We measure the initRD of the system And finally no vendor lock in at all 100  open source It's a sandbox project from the CNCF Now since we're talking about immutability I want to explain a little bit how the immutability works at I think it works similarly with most of those operating systems But this is how we do it At the center you have what we call strictly mutable This is where the things that you really don't want to change in your system those are mounted read only One example var lib So that means that if for some reason you're doing a package installation you can type the command but the result will tell you no I'm sorry I cannot write into this system so I cannot add a That means that that base that is strictly immutable will not change at all Then we have a different area that we call persistent This is information that you want to have accessible across upgrades Remember that an upgrade is not changing the system itself but introducing a completely new system So that means that those two systems must have access to certain areas of the disk In this case for your home directory Whether I use what we call the A partition or the B partition it doesn't matter which of the two I access I might want to access And finally you have certain areas of the system that are completely writable For example the logs If the system could not write the logs it would be pretty useless right So you must be able to fully write in it The process to convert certain to create an appliance with Kairos is very straightforward You define your system to build images So you build as many as you want In this case every commit should be a new image for example And then you might need to load it into a system or not Like if you are provisioning you might need to load it If you are upgrading you might not because you can use the repository to do the upgrades And finally you just need to boot the appliance and it's going to be running just like when you boot an Alexa when you boot any of these systems that are just ready to run A little bit more on detail on how this is done Like I was saying you start with code It's Dockerfiles and YAML so our bread and butter when it comes to Kubernetes Then Kairos comes and helps you initializing that into a container image That container image will have something special which is that it will include the Linux kernel hence why I have the tux sitting there And then you might need like I was saying to bootstrap it into an ISO or a USB where we also help you to do that This maps very well to what we call day zero operations where you are designing your systems Then for day one we provision that system You might have different ways Again it's not the same if you are provisioning something in the data center than if you are provisioning a Raspberry Pi right That will be more a bit on your side But on our side we are going to make sure that that system that you are booting that you are provisioning sorry is completely following the immutability that we just talked about And also in case you need that degree of security that you also have trusted boot in your machine And finally for the day two operations so this is the part where the end user might not even want to care what you are running there They just want to be able to reboot in case there is a problem Well we provide like I said the atomic upgrades rollbacks In case an upgrade didn't function correctly it will just run the previous system that was running on the machine so that you can also do factory resets basically Thank you Mauro So these are some projects that are in the CNCF and on that are supporting us with
